docs.lead_paragraph: More health maintenance organizations will soon pull out of Medicare or curtail their participation, disrupting insurance coverage for hundreds of thousands of elderly people, according to federal officials, independent experts and managed-care executives. Despite pledges by the Clinton administration to slow the withdrawal of H.M.O.'s from Medicare, the insurance program for the elderly, the exodus may actually accelerate this year, a White House official and several experts said.

headline.main: More H.M.O.'s Quit Medicare, Stirring Turmoil

docs.abstract: More health maintenance organizations will soon pull out of Medicare or curtail their participation, citing low reimbursement rates; Cigna Corp and Aetna are the latest; Rep Nancy L Johnson says Medicare has smothered HMO's with regulations and starved them with low payments; Clinton administration officials say they want to preserve HMO's as an option for the elderly and the disabled, but has opposed industry's efforts to get more money because they believe that HMO's are overpaid; beneficiaries dropped by insurers will have to find another HMO or return to Medicare's original fee-for-service program; withdrawals of last two years appear to have undermined beneficiaries' confidence in HMO's, slowing growth in enrollment (M)
docs.snippet: More health maintenance organizations will soon pull out of Medicare or curtail their participation, disrupting insurance coverage for hundreds of thousands of elderly people, according to federal officials, independent  experts and managed-care...

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Two radiologists whose licenses were suspended by the state this week following accusations that the doctors administered faulty mammograms have a history of problems in their practices, according to state records and interviews with former medical associates. On Wednesday, the state health commissioner, Dr. Antonia C. Novello, asserted that Dr. Steven J. Bier and Dr. Mario DiBlasio improperly screened 9,000 to 11,000 poor women in the last five years in the Bronx for breast cancer, often billing for tests they did not provide.
docs.abstract: Two radiologists whose licenses were suspended by state following accusations of faulty administration of mammograms have history of problems in practices; State Health Commissioner Dr Antonia C Novello asserts that Dr Steven J Bier and Dr Mario DiBlasio improperly screened 9,000 to 11,000 poor Bronx women during last five years for breast cancer, often billing for tests not provided; Dr DiBlasio has history of drug addiction, was convicted of narcotics sale and possession and sentenced to 21 years to life in prison, however investigation shows that he has made efforts toward rehabilitation; case highlights state's difficulty in deciding doctor's fate; Dr Bier improperly billed insurance companies; state has accused both doctors of gross negligence and incompetence and they await formal disciplinary hearing; former state health commissioner Dr Mark Chassin says process must be 'wise and flexible' weighing protection of public against removing ability of physician to practice medicine (M)
docs.snippet: Two radiologists whose licenses were suspended by the state this week following accusations that the doctors administered faulty mammograms have a history of problems in their practices, according to state records and interviews with former medical...

docs.lead_paragraph: Few may have noticed, but last week saw another step in the dismantling of New York's pioneering social benefit system. Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general, announced that he would no longer oppose converting Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to a for-profit corporation. Over the past decade, various government and nonprofit health, housing and cultural institutions have been turned into money-making entities outside of public control. Slowly, the city and state are giving away a civic patrimony that earlier generations of New Yorkers built with their money, imagination and political will.

headline.main: Chipping Away at the Community of New York

docs.abstract: Joshua B Freeman Op-Ed article opposes conversion of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield from a nonprofit health insurer into a for-profit corporation; says its problems, which stem from both mismanagment and competition that picked off its healthiest customers, leaving the organization with the sickest, most expensive clients, can be addressed without privatization (M)
docs.snippet: Few may have noticed, but last week saw another step in the dismantling of New York's pioneering social benefit system. Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general, announced that he would no longer oppose converting Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 Putin Suggests New Way To Foil Missile Attacks President Vladimir Putin of Russia, seeking to recast a security debate just before his summit meeting with President Clinton, has suggested an alternative to the proposed American system for defending against missile attacks by nations like North Korea. Mr. Putin hinted that the United States and Russia could collaborate on new ways to shoot down missiles soon after they were launched, rather than in space. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, the nation's third-largest health insurer, said yesterday that it had sold a portion of its United States reinsurance operations to the Life Reassurance Corporation of America for $170 million. Cigna, based in Philadelphia, said it wanted to focus more on its employee benefit operations. Cigna said the businesses it sold included its United States individual and group life reinsurance businesses as well as its United States accidental death reinsurance business. Those businesses had revenue of $100 million last year. Over all, Cigna has about $8.8 billion in annual revenue. Life Reassurance, based in Stamford, Conn., is the United States subsidiary of the Swiss Reinsurance Company, a privately held Swiss company.

headline.main: CIGNA SELLS PORTION OF ITS REINSURANCE BUSINESS

docs.abstract: Life Reassurance, subsidiary of Swiss Reinsurance Co, buys part of Cigna Corp's reinsurance operations (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Unemployment Rate Rose To 4.1 Percent Last Month In the strongest signal yet that the booming economy is finally slowing, the Labor Department reported that the nation's private sector employers shed 116,000 jobs in May. It was the largest drop in more than eight years and the first decline since the economy began to soar in the mid-1990's.

docs.lead_paragraph: Invoking World War II and the race to the moon, Vice President Al Gore promised today to double federal spending on cancer research and to make ''a flood'' of new cancer treatments and tests available to all Americans who need them. In a speech brimming with soaring oratory and buoyant optimism, Mr. Gore described the nation as standing on the brink of medical breakthroughs fueled by genetic research, and called on the federal government to use its resources to turn those discoveries into preventing and curing the most fatal cancers.

headline.main: Gore Urges Doubling of Funds in War Against Cancer

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidate Vice Pres Al Gore, in speech at Emory University Medical School, promises to double federal spending on cancer research if elected and to make 'flood' of new cancer treatments and tests available to all Americans who need them; describes nation as standing on brink of medical breakthrough fueled by genetic research, and calls on federal government to use resources to turn discoveries into preventing and curing most fatal cancers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DANIEL BROWN, a 32-year-old lawyer in Bethesda, Md., got the news in February that he had chronic myelogenous leukemia and that no one in his family had the proper genetic match to donate life-saving bone marrow. The disease kills 60 percent to 70 percent of patients within five years of diagnosis, according to bone-marrow specialists. ''Time is not on your side,'' said Mr. Brown's wife, Jolie. ''So some families do their own bone-marrow drive, and that's what we've done. We're not going to sit around and wait.''

headline.main: Searching the Web as a Matter of Life and Death

docs.abstract: Family of Daniel Brown, lawyer in Bethesda, Md, who has chronic myelogenious leukemia, established their own Web site to speed up process for finding suitable bone-marrow donors; site is also linked to National Bone Marrow Donor Program (www.marrow,org) and the donor program Browns are working with, Gift of Life Foundation (www.hlamatch.org); Browns are among growing number of families using Internetb to find potential donors; there are dozens of independent bone-marrow and related registries worldwide, and they do not share all their information; most, but not all, do share basic tissue data for more than 6.4 million people worldwide who have given samples and this data is forwarded to Bone Marrow Donors Worldworld (wwwbmdw.org); group's Web site is open to doctors and public; photo of Brown family (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. and the ING Group, the Dutch financial services company, said yesterday that they were discussing a new offer from ING to buy Aetna's financial and international divisions. Aetna declined to discuss the price under negotiation, but some Wall Street traders estimated it could be as high as $9 billion, only slightly less than the roughly $10 billion ING had offered for all of Aetna earlier this year. Aetna shares rose $5 at midday after CNBC reported the ING offer, and closed up $4.0625 at $66.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline.main: ING and Aetna Renew Talks; Partial Sale Is Considered

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc and ING Group are discussing new offer from ING to buy Aetna's financial and international divisions; Aetna declines to discuss price under negotiation, but some Wall Street traders speculate on offer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More and more in recent years, private insurance has been picking up the cost of prescription medicine. Only about one-quarter of Americans' total drug costs are now paid out of pocket. That is why there is no general political uproar even though drug prices in the United States have been rising by as much as 15 percent a year, the drug makers are among the most profitable businesses in the world and many new drugs in Canada and Europe cost a small fraction of what they do here.

headline.main: Health Insurance Provides Buffer to Rising Drug Prices for Most Americans

docs.abstract: Analysis of increasing insurance coverage of prescription drugs; trend, result of shift to health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care, has muted reaction to skyrocketing drug prices; elderly who depend on Medicare, which does not cover outpatient drugs, bear brunt of price rises and are up in arms; graph (M)
